Ten science questions answered: https://morepotatoes.com/2018/02/23/q-and-a-part-2-science/

6:44 That's not an accurate description of what is happening. The light shining on the metal is partially absorbed, exciting the electrons into a higher energetic state. When these excited electrons "fall" back into their original energy state they release energy in the form of light. The wavelength of the emitted light depends on the difference of the energy states.

Modern concrete has lime removed because it dissolves in water overtime causing the concrete to crumble. Whereas when mixed with salt water this creates "hydrated lime" which is then incorporated in the mixture when it cures. The water is in there technically but it can't erode the cement over time as its chemically bonded.

Roman concrete is actually pretty easy to make.If you gather some limestone or even seashells, and then let it sit in the flames of a fire for 4-5 hours they'll begin turn red, but once they obtain the crimson color they're ready to be taken out and mixed with other ingredients.You then add water after the limestone has been heated, and you want to mix the two until you reach a thich pasty consistency.After you're done with that you'll need to add volcanic ash + pumice and stir all of it together until it's completely mixed.You'll then want to put your concerete in a mold and let it solidify.

I heard that what really makes modern concrete deteriorate so fast is the rebar we use to reinforce it. Moisture and oxygen seep into the porous concrete, making the rebar rust and increase in volume, putting great pressure on the concrete and cracking it from inside.
